title: CROSS OF IRON FANZINE
historical_context: This issue is part of the early underground zine culture, reflecting the heavy metal and punk scenes of the late 1980s, a time when censorship and the PMRC were significant issues.
target_audience: Metal enthusiasts, punk fans, underground music supporters, and those interested in the history of music censorship.
short_summary: This issue of CROSS OF IRON features a variety of album reviews, commentary on censorship in music, and a call to action against the PMRC. It encapsulates the raw energy and rebellious spirit of the late 1980s underground music scene.
summary: CROSS OF IRON, the official e-zine of the Cult of the Dead Cow, serves as a vibrant snapshot of the underground music scene in 1988. This issue is packed with reviews of various metal and punk albums, showcasing the raw and unfiltered opinions of its contributors. The zine not only reviews music but also addresses the pressing issue of censorship, particularly the influence of the PMRC, which sought to regulate music deemed inappropriate. The writers passionately argue for the importance of artistic freedom and the right to express oneself through music, urging readers to sign a petition against censorship efforts. The zine's tone is irreverent and unapologetic, reflecting the ethos of the underground culture it represents, making it a compelling read for anyone interested in the history of music and its intersection with societal issues.
additional_notes: The zine includes a mix of humor, critique, and a sense of community among fans of heavy music, making it a significant artifact of its time.
